I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  Road transport in Bangladesh. Road is the dominant transport mode in Bangladesh, 
with a modal share of over 70% of passenger traffic and 60% of freight traffic.1 Road traffic has 
been growing at an average rate of over 6.6% per year between 2016 and 2020.2 The number of 
vehicles has also increased by 15% annually since 2015, reaching 4.4 million in 2020.3 The key 
challenges for Bangladesh’s roads are limited capacity, deteriorating conditions, missing links 
across the country’s many rivers, and the mixture of traffic of differing speeds.4 
 
2.  Dhaka–Sylhet  corridor.  Upgrading  of  the  Dhaka–Sylhet  corridor—the  main  part  of 
National Highway No. 2 (N2) and the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) 
Road Corridor No. 5—has been the government’s top priority for completing the country’s 
multimodal transport system.5 Once completed, the corridor will open up a new trade route 
connecting Chattogram via Dhaka and Sylhet to the border with the northeastern states of India 
through the land ports of Akhaura, Sheola, and Tamabil, and thereby to Bhutan and Myanmar. It 
will also improve the connectivity of SASEC Corridor No. 2, passing from Kolkata in India through 
Benapole, and Corridor No. 5 that connects Dhaka to Sylhet. This will decongest the Dhaka–
Chattogram corridor on National Highway No. 1 by allowing more goods, especially raw materials, 
to be imported via Tamabil and transported along the Dhaka–Sylhet corridor. 
 
3.  However, the Dhaka‒Sylhet road has only two lanes with no provision for slow-moving 
and light traffic, leading to capacity constraints and significant safety risks. This has prevented 
the Dhaka–Sylhet corridor from meeting the need for a vital subregional trade corridor and 
providing inclusive mobility to the poor and vulnerable living along the corridor. The situation is 
further  exacerbated  by  climate  change,  which  increases  flooding  risks,  particularly  in  the 
northeastern wetland districts where low-lying areas remain submerged for 4–6 months during 
pre-monsoon and monsoon seasons. 
 
3.  The proposed SASEC Dhaka–Sylhet Corridor Road Investment Project will finance the 
improvement of about 210 kilometers (km) of the Dhaka–Sylhet section of the N2 from a two-lane 
road to a four-lane road with slow-moving vehicular traffic service lanes, and with design features 
that take into account the needs of the elderly, women, children, and the differently abled, and 
disaster and climate risks.6 By connecting to the borders with India via the Sylhet–Tamabil section, 
the project road will improve efficiency, connectivity, and safety of the Dhaka–Sylhet trade corridor. 
 
4.  The investment project is aligned with the following impact: an efficient, sustainable, safe, 
and regionally balanced transportation system developed.7 The investment project will have the 
following outcome: mobility, safety, and regional trade along the Dhaka–Sylhet corridor improved. 
This will be delivered through the following outputs: (i) the Dhaka–Sylhet corridor road upgraded 
with enhanced road safety; elderly, women, children, and differently abled-responsive; and 
climate- and disaster-resilient features; and (ii) institutional capacity of the Roads and Highways 
Department (RHD) enhanced.

2 
 
5.  The investment project is estimated to cost $2,691.0 million, including taxes and duties, 
land acquisition and resettlement costs, physical and price contingencies, interest, and other 
charges during implementation. The government has requested a multitranche financing facility 
in  an  amount  of  up  to  $1,780.0  million  from  the  ordinary  capital  resources  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to help finance part of the investment project. The investment project 
is included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Bangladesh, 2021−2023.8 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
 
6.  Road  safety.  The  World  Health  Organization  estimates  road  traffic  fatalities  in 
Bangladesh total almost 25,000 annually, while the figure reported by the government is about 
2,000.9 The significant discrepancies between official statistics and independent estimates point 
to possible underreporting, attributable to deficiencies in data collection, management, and 
utilization. This could constrain the RHD and other road safety agencies as they seek to formulate 
effective road safety actions. Accidents are increasing in severity, with a high proportion of road 
fatalities involving collisions between heavy and/or high-speed vehicles such as buses and trucks 
and pedestrians.10 The annual national economic loss related to road casualties is estimated to 
be about $715.0 million, or nearly 2% of the country’s gross domestic product. 
 
7.  Limited capacity of the Roads and Highways Department. The RHD’s capacity for 
collecting, managing, and analyzing accident data is limited. It lacks the capacity to collect 
accident data, and instead relies on the Bangladesh Police for data collection, but which has 
provided no official accident data since 2015. The Microcomputer Accident Analysis Package 5 
database, the current accident report and management format used by the RHD and other 
agencies responsible for road safety, including the Bangladeshi Police and Accident Research 
Institute at the Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology, is obsolete, and the lack 
of access to data is causing inconvenience. The RHD lacks an institutional mechanism to analyze 
and use accident data for road network development, and road safety audit guidelines have not 
been incorporated effectively in planning and design. These limitations can prevent the RHD from 
fulfilling  its  mandate  of  planning  and  implementing  infrastructure  solutions  for  road  safety, 
especially to prevent fatal and severe accidents. 
 
8.  Challenges in operation and maintenance. Globally, Bangladesh ranks 100th out of 
141 countries in terms of the quality of its overall transport infrastructure, and 108th in the quality 
of its roads,11 lagging behind neighboring countries in the region.12 The suboptimal quality of its 
road network is affecting the country’s logistics performance. Bangladesh ranks 100th out of 160 
countries in the Logistics Performance Index, with an infrastructure indicator of 2.39 below the 
country’s overall average score of 2.58.13 Logistics service providers overwhelmingly point to 
inadequate road conditions and congestion as main reasons for delays in shipment in the 
country.14 
 
 
8  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan, Bangladesh 2021–2023. Manila. 
9  World Health Organization. 2018. Global Status Report on Road Safety 2018. Geneva. 
10  The increase in the rate of deaths per accident in Bangladesh during 1990–2017 was 3 times higher than in other 
South Asian countries. World Bank. 2020. Delivering Road Safety in Bangladesh: Leadership Priorities and Initiatives 
to 2030. Washington, DC; and M. Hoque et al. 2010. Improving Highway Safety in Bangladesh: Road Improvement 
and the Potential Application of iRAP.  Melbourne. 
11  World Economic Forum. 2019. Global Competitiveness Report 2019. Geneva.  
12  In terms of quality of roads, India ranks at 48, Pakistan 67, the People’s Republic of China 45, Sri Lanka 76, and 
Vietnam 103.  
13  World Bank. 2019. The Logistics Performance Indicator 2018. Washington, DC.  
14  World Bank. 2020. Moving Forward: Connectivity and Logistics to Sustain Bangladesh’s Success. Washington, DC.

3 
9.  Remaining challenges to sustainability. The RHD is aiming to maintain a good-to-fair 
assessment for 95% of its total road network. It has implemented various reforms to reach this 
goal: (i) introducing an annual road condition and service-level assessment process for projecting 
5-year investment needs, (ii) establishing the Road and Bridge Asset Management System 
(2004‒2005),  (iii)  piloting  performance-based  maintenance, 15 and  increasing  maintenance 
spending on national highways. While these actions have resulted in steady improvement in the 
condition of its road network, the RHD needs further efforts to improve its maintenance framework 
and ensure sustainability of its expanding road network. The maintenance budget framework must 
be reformed to adequately reflect assessed road conditions in the maintenance budget proposals. 
The outdated road asset database and limited field validation of assessed needs, with consequent 
low reliability of information on road conditions, also need to be improved. Strategies for long-
term sustainability must also be in place. The Road Maintenance Fund Board Act, enacted in 
2013, has to be made functional with assured funding and arrangements for transferring proceeds 
of the fund to maintenance operations. The RHD’s capacity for enforcing the Motor Vehicle Axle 
Load Control Regulations enacted in 2012 also needs to be strengthened.16 
 
10.  Gender  equality  and  social  inclusion.  Women’s  mobility  needs  have  risen  in 
Bangladesh as more women have entered the workforce at pace with the country’s economic 
growth. However, the road sector has faced constraints in responding to women’s needs, which 
differ from those of men. In particular, the poor condition of roads and lack of features for gender 
equality and social inclusion (GESI) in the current road design make it unsafe to travel for 
vulnerable groups such as women, children, the elderly, and the differently-abled. To address 
these issues, strengthening of the RHD’s GESI institutional capacity is essential. 
 
11.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will help the RHD address the key challenges 
for the road subsector through the following outputs: (i) improving the RHD’s capacity in collection 
and management of road accident data, (ii) enhancing its capacity in road safety audit and 
formulation of a road safety road map, (iii) strengthening its capacity in planning and implementing 
road maintenance, and (iv) improving its institutional capacity on GESI. The transaction TA is 
included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Bangladesh, 2021−2023 (footnote 8). 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Capacity of the Roads and Highways Department in road accident data 
collection and management system improved 
(i)  Validate  the  baseline  value  for  outcome  performance  indicator  (b)  in  the 
investment project design and monitoring framework.17 
(ii)  Provide staff training on collection of road accident field data, including 
(a) appropriate and adequate sources from which to collect field data and/or 
information; 
(b) type of data and/or information to be collected, including sex-disaggregated 
data; and 
(c) management of data after collection. 
 
15  The RHD has published an annual Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation Needs Report since 1999. ADB. 2012. 
Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Administration of Loan 
and Technical Assistance Grant to People’s Republic of Bangladesh: South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation 
Road Connectivity Project. Manila. 
16  The RHD is constructing 28 new axle load control stations on its highways through the Installation of Axle Load 
Control Stations at the Origins and Destinations of Freight Transport on Important Highways Project. Since 2013, 
the RHD has been also mainstreaming the use of polymer modified bitumen, which is believed to be more resistant 
to higher traffic volume and overloading.  
17  Outcome indicator (b): total road fatalities per 100,000,000 vehicle-km travelled along the project road reduced by 
20%  (2021  baseline:  6.53).  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in  Appendix  1  of  the  Report  and 
Recommendation of the President for the investment project.

4 
(iii)  Review the system under the RHD-related to road accident data collection and 
management, including the processing of accident report forms by Microcomputer 
Accident Analysis Package 5 software. When necessary and/or relevant, collect 
information on and assess similar systems used or piloted in Bangladesh or 
developing member countries with similar traffic situations (e.g., Data for Road 
Incident Visualization, Evaluation and Reporting [DRIVER]), currently piloted in 
Dhaka). 
(iv)  Propose an effective and cost-efficient alternative to the existing system, with an 
emphasis on the RHD having its own accident data collection and management 
capacity, and exploring the use of current technology.18 
(v)  Provide training on the use of the new system and improve knowledge of road 
accident data analysis through the application of the new system. 
(vi)  Develop a structured approach to evaluating and identifying the causes of fatal 
and severe road accidents based on the data collected. 
(vii)  Evaluate  the  current  institutional  arrangements  and  capacity  of  the  RHD  in 
processing accident data, running the database, and analyzing the data, and 
estimate additional resources required to introduce the proposed alternative. 
(viii)  Coordinate with the Bangladesh Road Transport Authority, Highway Police, and 
the  Accident  Research  Institute  on  knowledge  sharing  and  collaboration  for 
continuous improvement of the data collection system. 
(ix)  Launch the RHD’s secure online road accident database and provide access to all 
relevant government agencies and stakeholders. 
(x)  Develop a new framework using the evaluation results based on the approach in 
(iii) and incorporate the results to improve the RHD road design.19 
 
13.  Output 2: Capacity of the Roads and Highways Department in road safety audit 
  enhanced 
(i)  Review the current institutional and legal framework for road safety audit under the 
RHD. 
(ii)  Review  and  strengthen  the  current  road  safety  audit  procedures,  including 
guidelines,  manuals,  and  procedure  notes  such  as  on  Road  Safety  Audit 
Guidelines. 
(iii)  Develop monitoring and evaluation procedures, such as monitoring of accident-
prone sites before and after proposed safety and/or rectification measures are 
implemented  to  evaluate  their  effectiveness  through  road  safety  audits  and 
inspections. 
(iv)  Identify the additional institutional resources required to ensure road safety audits 
and inspections are acceptable. 
(v)  Analyze road accident characteristics and trends using data collected under output 
1 and the monitoring and evaluation procedures in (iii) under output 2. 
(vi)  Develop a road safety road map to enhance the RHD’s road safety framework, 
including plans (short-, medium-, and long-term) and safety audit programs. 
(vii)  Conduct road safety audits on selected RHD roads and highways. 
(viii)  Coordinate with all key road safety agencies and relevant stakeholders on the 
latest road safety audit procedures to secure their support and cooperation. 
(ix)  Develop a business process for ongoing improvement of safety audit procedures 
that incorporate the safety audit results under (vii) to improve the RHD’s road 
design. 
 
18  Examples can include interlinking the road accident database with the RHD’s geocoded map of national highways 
with the help of global positioning satellite and accident data. 
19  Examples can include identification of accident-prone locations and evaluation of why more accidents occur in these 
locations. Evaluation results can be used to formulate road design guidelines and/or requirements to reduce accident 
risk.

5 
 
14.  Output 3: Capacity of the Roads and Highways Department in road maintenance 
strengthened 
(i)  Review the existing policy and governance framework for road maintenance under 
the RHD, including the strategy and program for road maintenance. 
(ii)  Review the effectiveness of the current road maintenance needs assessment tool 
using the Highway Development and Management 4 (HDM-4) model to prioritize 
maintenance work, assess improvement needs, and estimate required investment. 
This may require conducting a rapid assessment of selected roads to validate the 
RHD’s assessment results and maintenance cost estimate. 
(iii)  Develop a new alternative and/or supplementary tool in addition to the HDM-4 
model. 
(iv)  Review the condition of the most recent road maintenance works undertaken by 
the RHD using the tool introduced in (iii). 
(v)  Identify  key  bottlenecks  in  the  current  road  maintenance  budget  framework 
(including programming and implementation) and develop a reform action plan. 
(vi)  Identify solutions for optimizing maintenance investments based on life cycle cost 
analysis, including the use of new materials, construction methods, and equipment. 
(vii)  Assist the RHD in updating and/or revising the current maintenance manuals to be 
in line with applicable international good practice. 
(viii)  Provide training to the RHD staff, including field office staff, on an improved budget 
programing framework and maintenance activities based on revised manuals. 
(ix)  Study optimal public–private partnership modalities for national highways and 
prepare case studies for three priority highways, including the Dhaka–Sylhet road. 
 
15.  Output 4: Institutional support for the Roads and Highways Department in gender 
equality and social inclusion provided 
(i)  Develop manuals and/or guidelines to incorporate GESI-responsive and climate 
and disaster resilience features in road design. 
(ii)  Formulate a GESI strategy for the RHD. 
(iii)  Undertake the following studies: 
(a) determine which road safety billboard messages and locations would have the 
largest road safety impact, and 
(b) evaluate current bus station designs and explore ways to improve designs for 
socially vulnerable groups (e.g., women, the elderly, and children).20 
(iv)  Provide workshops and training, including 
(a) undertaking activities (i) and (ii) with the RHD headquarters and district offices; 
(b) training of the RHD trainers so they can offer road safety training to teachers 
and students at schools; and 
(c) educating the public on road safety through various media for slow-moving 
vehicle users, and providing good practices from other countries. 
(v)  Conduct a final presentation on the outcome of activities (i) and (ii) with key 
personnel at the RHD headquarters. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $3,250,000, of which (i) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-7), and (ii) $ 2,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) and administered by ADB.21 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
 
20 Examples include installation of closed-circuit television or CCTV and roadside lighting. 
21 The JFPR is a possible funding source subject to approval by the Government of Japan.

6 
17.  ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund will support activities related to outputs 3 and 
4 and the JFPR will support activities related to outputs 1 and 2. 
 
18.  Relevant government agencies will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff, data and reports, and other in-kind contributions. .

Asia Department will be responsible for selection, supervision, and evaluation of the consultants.
